Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF IUCRC Center for Disruptive Musculoskeletal Innovations (CDMI) is hosting a public workshop in collaboration with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) entitled "Orthopedic Sensing, Measuring, and Advanced Reporting Technology (SMART) Devices". The goal of the workshop is to: 1) to gain better understanding of current state and future possibilities of Orthopedic SMART device technology; and 2) begin to identify/establish appropriate regulatory framework to promote use of the technology and protect public health. Public input and feedback gained through this workshop may aid in the efficient development of innovative, safe and effective, orthopaedic SMART devices, for better patient care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) hosted a public workshop in collaboration with the NSF I/UCRC Center for Disruptive Musculoskeletal Innovations (CDMI) entitled "Orthopaedic Sensing, Measuring, and Advanced Reporting Technology (SMART) Devices" on April 30, 2018. The event was held at the FDA White Oak Campus in Silver Spring, Maryland and NSF awarded CDMI an NSF conference grant to pay for the travel and accommodations of the invited speakers.

The purpose of the public workshop was to discuss the growing interest in incorporating sensors in musculoskeletal implants and the related regulatory considerations. The workshop was also intended to enhance engagement between the FDA, clinicians, researchers, musculoskeletal organizations, the public, and manufacturing, cybersecurity, and research companies to facilitate device development and to discuss scientific and regulatory challenges associated with Orthopaedic SMART Devices.

There were 4 consecutive sessions with speakers in each that ended in panel discussions and question/answer period:

  • Engineering/Technology ? introduced the current landscape of SMART technology, industry adoption, and explore future applications of this technology
  • Clinical/Patient Perspective ? covered the importance and potential utility and impact of these technologies for clinicians and patients and considerations for adopting these new technologies into existing healthcare paradigms
  • Cybersecurity ? reviewed current cybersecurity issues and solutions and healthcare/SMART data management and FDA?s cybersecurity regulatory considerations
  • Regulatory/Real World Evidence ? covered FDA?s regulatory process, clinical trial innovations, digital health initiatives, and Orthopaedic SMART device evaluation

Thanks to joint collaboration of the FDA, the CDMI, and the NSF conference grant, the event was a success and attracted 241 in-person registrants and had a peak of 125 online viewers. The intent of the workshop was met and began many dialogues among the various stakeholders mentioned above. In addition, the workshop gave FDA insights into novel technologies that are already in orthopaedic commercialization pipelines so the FDA can allocate their resources appropriately and better develop review polices to advance their mission of protecting and promoting public health. The FDA also was able to provide companies and healthcare professionals a better understanding of the regulatory pathways and types of supporting data that they may have access to that can assist them in their research and their FDA submissions. Moreover, since some CDMI?s Industry Advisory Board members attended, data from the workshop maybe incorporated in the CDMI?s Research Roadmap as areas to pursue in future calls for proposals from CDMI faculty.

The summary of this workshop and key concepts and questions/challenges that were raised by the public during the session are currently being written up in a white paper led by the FDA.  The white paper will offer a concise summary of the event and propose future steps that may  aid in the efficient development of innovative, safe and effective, Orthopaedic SMART devices, for better patient care. For more information including the webcast recordings, transcripts, slides, and invited guest biographies, please visit:

https://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/NewsEvents/WorkshopsConferences/ucm595401.htm
